div.p: Starting in 1826, the archiveʼs earliest documents reveal the Ruskin familyʼs engagement with late-Enlightenment pedagogy for young children; extending to 1842, later documents open up the experiences of an early Victorian Oxonian and the professionalization of a rising author.but, when complete, it will be the most comprehensive. Approximately a third of its materials has never before been available in edited form, and a large portion of the remainder has been available only in the problematically edited form of late-nineteenth- and early-twentieth-century editions. The archive also encourages awareness of the editorial, scholarly, and biographical tradition in which it stands, inviting critical assessment of a tradition of reflection on Ruskinʼs youth and education.Among the most multifaceted thinkers of the nineteenth century, Ruskin developed an approach to art criticism that probed the social, religious, political, and economic implications of appreciating beauty in the arts and the natural world. ERM contains the records of his education leading to that career,

Once the task of organizing, annotating, and exhibiting this mass of material is well underway, the archive also aims to facilitate study of how Ruskin became seemingly the most proto-hypertextual of Victorian writers. Late in his career, Ruskin experimented with writing and publication that anticipate modes later made possible by digital platforms. Straining the publication resources of his day, he invented an unbounded and hypertextual, if perhaps not quite nonlinear, series of monthly letters called Fors Clavigera. It is a valuable question how far Ruskinʼs innovations were grounded, for example, in a social-network methods of education promoted by the Edgeworths, or in a Romantic-era alertness to the interrelation of arts and disciplines.

In such questions and in the ongoing digitization of Ruskinʼs works, ERM joins other digital editions such as the Ruskinʼs Venetian Notebooks, and The Elements of Drawing. ERM most directly complements the Lancaster University's Electronic Edition of Modern Painters I, in the sense that the present archive can be viewed as editing the works leading up to that 1843 work, which established Ruskinʼs reputation as a popular art critic.

A complementary volume of early prose edited by Collingwood was planned but never executed. Instead, Allen was responsible for a small, somewhat haphazard miscellany of volumes of early prose writing, perhaps meant more to ply the heated trade for fine editions of fugitive writing by “modern writers” than to serve scholarship.

Thus, the transmission of Ruskinʼs early writing at the turn of the twentieth century is bound up, on one hand, with Ruskinʼs construction of his youth in the autobiographical narratives of Fors Clavigera and Praeterita, and, on another hand, with the cultural context of fine book collecting centering on modern authors that flourished in the 1890s. ERM provides a means to study these later contexts of transmission of the early Ruskin, which helped to shape subsequent scholarship, as well as the contexts of the early writingʼs first creation. Building on this tradition and (it is hoped) contributing new avenues of scholarship, ERM assembles digital facsimiles of the manuscripts along with transcripts encoded according to the standards of the Text Encoding Initiative (TEI), allowing for expansion in content and extensibility in markup unavailable to earlier editors. The edition is offered as an interdisciplinary research site for a new generation of Romantic and Victorian studies.
